subject: Fix Short read/write issue
commitMessage:
Fix Short read/write issue

It was possible for "short" reads and writes to cause the pattern and
zero steps to not work correctly. This change adds logic to deal with
the short reads.

Tested: unit test and machine test
root@bmc# time busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 \
> /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/storage/mmcblk0 \
> xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume Erase s \
> xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume.EraseMethod.ZeroOverWrite \
> --timeout=1200
real    6m0.815s
user    0m0.010s
sys     0m0.010s

Change-Id: If8df9bdba159a3bcfa77104a4c17b8d352794db2
Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>

Add comment for the new parameter.
In the zero test, you have a test case where you read too much data. But you don't have that here.

Yep, I can add that test back.
Added back

It is intentional.
I wanted 3 chunks of data. short1, short2, restOfData?

Does the test ever get to the point of returning restOfData? It seems to me that it will just return shortData1 indefinitely.

It might make sense to have this conform to what you're doing in the zero test, where you just have several WillOnce() clauses in a row.

That is a fine idea.
I was under the impression that the InSequence would inforce the retires of the EXEPCT calls, but I am not an expert.

By using WillRepeatedly(), I think the test will just return shortData1 every time. There's no indication for when it should start returning restOfData. You can try adding print statement to confirm this behavior, if you want.

Yeah, I was following this example (http://google.github.io/googletest/gmock_cook_book.html#PartialOrder) for the ordering of calls. 

WillOnce does not automatically retire the saturated call. It needed the explicet
"RetiresOnSaturation".
Did you forget the verify step?

no I removed it, along with the expect reads.
I was not sure the complexity the expect_calls were worth it.
I think it makes sense to add the coverage for the verify portion, as well. You did it fairly concisely in the zero test.
Okay, if we want that, I might want some gmock experts to explain/advice on my test setup (and why did did not work as expected).
done. we are now exercising the verifyPattern also

I don't think InSequence is doing anything in this case.

My understanding of InSequence is that it's used to enforce a certain order of different function calls. You're not doing that. You are just changing the behavior of the mocked function as it gets called multiple times.

I think this is all you're trying to do. This is the type of thing you have in the zero test.

EXPECT_CALL(mock, write(_))
        .WillOnce(Return(shortData1))
        .WillOnce(Return(resetOfData))
        .WillOnce(Return(shortData2));

Okay, thanks.
Let me know if you see anything else.

I think it'd be better if you remove this line, and let your test call write() one more time, with the same behavior as before. This will make sure that your code throws an exception when the max retries is reached. Instead, you're having the write function throw the exception without testing your max retries logic.

makes sense, 
done. 32->33 and the last expect is removed.
Is there any testing that was done that we could put here?
I guess you added new unit test cases - might be good to just have Teated: New unit test coverage

Let's copy what we have for zero.hpp - let's move this one up to where the current writePattern() is (since the doxygen currently is not matching, as it has params)

And have a very short doxygen for the one without params.
prefer size_t unless there's a good reason to use it (according to openbmc style guide: https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#misc-guidelines)

done?

Confirm you want to store time in a size_t by checking resolved.

Ah sorry, delay is time.

Hmm, I guess the style guide says use int (since this is not count), but we know time is uint, so maybe we can just use uint here. Do you mind asking the discord to see if we should include "uint" in the preferred section? We could simply just update the doc and try adding uint and see what people say (best way to get response from people is to make wrong assumption, or something)
Andrew Jeffrey suggested using "struct timeval" which has tv_usec for microsecond that we can use instead here.

Patrick and I agree that std::chrono is the best for this application.
 
(I even prefer chrono to absl, but only slightly)
same as the other file, prefer size_t: https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#misc-guidelines

done?

Confirm you want to store time in a size_t by marking resolved.

heuristically. The our current system does not produce short read/writes
I am open to suggestions.
(just following the "written" variable used in pattern.cpp + it makes more sense)
is this supposed to be taken out?
should we have a short write fail test too?

It is named shortRead, but it test both short and short writes. 
I will adjust the name.
Oh, what lint error was this throwing?

Clang wants a destructor because a constructors was created in google mock

```
../src/test/erase/pattern_test.cpp:197:1: error: class 'ThrowExceptionAction' defines a copy constructor but does not define a destructor, a copy assignment operator, a move constructor or a move assignment operator [cppcoreguidelines-special-member-functions,-warnings-as-errors]
ACTION(ThrowException)
^
/usr/local/include/gmock/gmock-actions.h:1628:9: note: expanded from macro 'ACTION'
  class name##Action {                                                        \
        ^
```
I would rather not try to change google mock's macro if we did not have to.
I guess a bigger question may be - we don't seem to  be using ThrowException Action that we define. Is this needed?
turns out it is not needed, removed.
Should we have short write fail too?

the name is missleading the code below test both reads and writes.
Renamed.
same question as the other file

Clang wants a destructor because a constructors was created in google mock

```
../src/test/erase/pattern_test.cpp:197:1: error: class 'ThrowExceptionAction' defines a copy constructor but does not define a destructor, a copy assignment operator, a move constructor or a move assignment operator [cppcoreguidelines-special-member-functions,-warnings-as-errors]
ACTION(ThrowException)
^
/usr/local/include/gmock/gmock-actions.h:1628:9: note: expanded from macro 'ACTION'
  class name##Action {                                                        \
        ^
```
I would rather not try to change google mock's macro if we did not have to.
turns out it is not needed, removed.

whoa, first time seeing this being used.

I see that these are the "unlikely" paths and from my reading of the reference page, seems to be used correctly but curious (and to learn more), why did you decide to add these? Are they needed?

I did not intend to push this.

I will run test with and without them, and only keep them if they produce a substantial difference. A small percent of speed gain is not worth the programming complexity they add.

It will (likely:) speed up this section of the code. It takes more time to jump (in assembly) then not jump. So this used to change the instruction from (jump if equal) to (jump if not equal) and then swap the code paths.

However on modern systems the processors branch prediction optimization, dominates the jump/nojump distinction. So the implementation is more less clear.

It saved around 10 seconds, on 370 seconds. I deemed that not enough.
The attributes have been removed.
Let me know if anything needs attention.
I would think the previous way of sleeping after checking for maxRetry would be better since we don't have to sleep before we eventually throw - what was the rationale for moving it up here?

the original way made the thread sleep even when the first write worked.
This made the thread sleep around a 4M times for a duration of 1 milisecond, and that caused a timeout. 

So I added a logic not to sleep in the first read/write. I can move this logic donw after the throw by checking if retry is greater then 1, but I thought that would be more ugly (then comparing to zero).
I changed it to prevent the delay when throwing.

Ah that makes sense. Alternative, I wonder if it'd be cleaner (and logically make it very clear) if we did an `if (written == writeSize) {break}` check so that we don't have to go through the retry logic in the first place.

Because currently, we could actually pass the write on the last retry and it would throw.

That way, we don't need this retry check to skip the first try for sleep
good call. The break works well here.
Great! Looks much cleaner, thanks for cleaning up.
